timeline.message:
[KOGITO-3297] Bump CloudEvents api to 2.x

Signed-off-by: ruromero <rromerom@redhat.com>

timeline.bodyText: Can you please verify if this code works in native mode? As far as I remember this resource should be added to resources-config.json or similar to have it at runtime (also CloudEventsProvider could have similar problem to prevent class removal)
timeline.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText: Yes, this code works in native mode. Actually it will allow any other library using the addon to have the CloudEventsProvider injected without any additional configuration.
replies.author: ruromero

timeline.bodyText: Can you please verify if this is needed? Do we use jandex in the tests (and only in the tests)?
timeline.author: danielezonca
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1 +1,4 @@
-quarkus.log.level=INFO
\ No newline at end of file
+quarkus.log.level=INFO
+
+quarkus.index-dependency.cloudevents.group-id=io.cloudevents
+quarkus.index-dependency.cloudevents.artifact-id=cloudevents-http-restful-ws

replies.bodyText: No, it's not needed. With the service file it's enough to have the provider injected and available in other projects depending on this addon
replies.author: ruromero

replies.bodyText: Ok so it is not clear to me why you had to add this configuration only for the test. Shouldn't be possible to use service mechanism here too?
replies.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText: Yes, I deleted it
replies.author: ruromero

replies.bodyText:
I temporarily added it back and can be removed in cloudevents-2.0.0-milestone3
see cloudevents/sdk-java#233
replies.author: ruromero

timeline.bodyText: I don't think we should "hide" a serialization exception in an empty result. What about propagate the exception?
timeline.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText: Propagate the exception up to where? I need advise here
replies.author: ruromero

replies.bodyText:
@kostola
Can you please support? What if an event is impossible to be serialized? (same question for comment below)
replies.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText:
With the previous API the data field was typed, so there's no particular error handling for serialization errors.
Imho sending a CloudEvent with null data, as I see here, is not very useful. I would avoid that.
I would rather log a more detailed error (possibly with the payload that triggered the error somehow) so that in a production environment it's possible to investigate by grabbing the logs of the services.
Wdyt @danielezonca @ruromero ?
replies.author: kostola

replies.bodyText: Fine for me a more detailed log but what else? Error propagation until where?
replies.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText:
I would catch the exception, log the message without sending a CloudEvent with null data and then that's it in the code. It seems to me a very rare error but correct me if I'm wrong.
Then the best way imho to catch those errors in a prod environment would be to setup a log management system (e.g. Graylog) that ingests all the logs and allows custom triggers on specific messages to be configured.
Does this seem reasonable to you?
replies.author: kostola

replies.bodyText: Probably the best solution for this method would be to return a Optional<CloudEvent> and let the caller decide how to handle the serialization failure with something like ifPresentOrElse (which in my case would be to simply log the error without sending anything as I wrote above).
replies.author: kostola

replies.bodyText:
@ruromero
Can you please verify if the proposed approach can be implemented? Return Optional and log error in caller if empty
replies.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText:
@kostola logging the payload won't be of much help as it is an array of bytes representing anything (a Json object, a String, a serialized object in any language, etc.). In this case we expect an object of type E but if decoding failed you don't know how to represent the data content.
I think the log is fine as it is. It's an error saying the CloudEvent data cannot be deserialized with the stacktrace.
Regarding the Optional propagation. There are 2 chains of invocations:

BaseModelEventEmitter#publishDecisionModels. In this case it's simple, we decide whether to emit the event or not.
DefaultAggregator#aggregate: There are 2 invocations and for these cases the event is always created right before the invocation so it doesn't make sense to expect an error. If for some reason such error occurs I will throw an unchecked exception.
replies.author: ruromero

timeline.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText: I tried to propagate it but I didn't know up to where or where to really deal with it. Any advise?
replies.author: ruromero

timeline.bodyText: What is this module used for?
timeline.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText: It's not needed. I added it by mistake. Thanks
replies.author: ruromero
